G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease and tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14, which provides that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3\u20135.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3–5 because:

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The water intrusion and any related dampness, moisture, and structural conditions constitute violations of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to provisions requiring that:

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., landlords are required to maintain residential premises in compliance with minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including freedom from chronic dampness and water penetration.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Although this Complaint asserts only a cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, Plaintiff notes that Massachusetts law protects tenants from retaliatory conduct by landlords, including refusal to renew a lease after the tenant reports code violations.

G.L. c. 184, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant’s violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 is further supported by the broader Massachusetts public policy favoring safe and habitable housing and protecting tenants’ rights to report code violations, as reflected in G.L. c. 184, § 18 (restrictions on waivers of rights in leases), G.L. c. 93A (regulation of unfair or deceptive acts in trade or commerce), and the decisions in *Hemingway*, *Al-Ziab*, *Blackett*, and related cases.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: Defendant’s violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 is further supported by the broader Massachusetts public policy favoring safe and habitable housing and protecting tenants’ rights to report code violations, as reflected in G.L. c. 184, § 18 (restrictions on waivers of rights in leases), G.L. c. 93A (regulation of unfair or deceptive acts in trade or commerce), and the decisions in *Hemingway*, *Al-Ziab*, *Blackett*, and related cases.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including interference arising from serious sanitary code violations and uncorrected water leaks, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reaffirms that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment—such as serious sanitary conditions and water leaks—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In explaining the required level of fault, the court cites prior cases involving failure to control floods and repair a leaky roof as established examples of § 14 violations, thus directly supporting the proposition that substantial interference from such conditions breaches quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including interference arising from serious sanitary code violations and uncorrected water leaks, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment (here, severe noise from a lounge that the landlord could control) constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. However, the opinion does not address sanitary code violations, water leaks, or similar conditions; it focuses on noise and landlord control over another tenant’s operations. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about sanitary code violations and uncorrected water leaks, even though it supports the broader concept of substantial interference breaching quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including interference arising from serious sanitary code violations and uncorrected water leaks, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does hold that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the interference here is from criminal drug activity and lack of security measures, not from sanitary code violations or water leaks. The opinion does not address serious sanitary code violations or uncorrected water leaks as bases for breach of quiet enjoyment; those topics appear only in other cited cases, not this one. Thus, this decision does not support the specific proposition tying quiet enjoyment breaches to sanitary code violations and water leaks.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including interference arising from serious sanitary code violations and uncorrected water leaks, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that failure to provide heat, a serious sanitary code violation, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. However, the opinion does not discuss water leaks or interference arising from uncorrected water leaks at all. Thus it supports the general quiet-enjoyment-through-sanitary-code-violations point as to lack of heat, but not the broader proposition including water leaks specifically.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited.”

Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.proposition: Serious or chronic violations of the State Sanitary Code are evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses violations of the State Sanitary Code as breaches of an implied warranty or implied covenant tied to statutory housing standards, not as evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The text never frames code violations in terms of quiet enjoyment or treats them as establishing or evidencing a quiet-enjoyment breach, and the author is explicitly limiting his analysis to statutory/code-based habitability obligations. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Hemingway v. Commonwealth, 363 Mass. 184.relevant_excerpt: “I would state it to be (a) that by renting a dwelling unit a landlord impliedly agrees, with respect to the minimum standards prescribed by any applicable laws, regulations or codes (such as the State Sanitary Code) having the force and effect of law, (i) that the rented unit complies with such standards at the time of the renting, and (ii) that he will do whatever such laws, regulations or codes require a landlord to do for compliance with such standards during the term of the renting… and (d) that if the landlord fails in any material respect to comply with the prescribed minimum standards the tenant may…recover the excess of the amount paid over and above the fair value of the occupancy of the deficient premises.”}

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Serious or chronic violations of the State Sanitary Code are evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses using violations of the State Sanitary Code as the substantive content of an implied warranty/covenant relating to habitability and rent liability, but it does not address or link such violations to the separate doctrine of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The judge frames Code violations as evidence of breach of an implied agreement to meet statutory minimum standards, not as a breach of quiet enjoyment, and the quiet enjoyment covenant is not analyzed here. Thus, this text does not provide authority for the specific proposition that serious or chronic Sanitary Code violations are evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Young v. Patrons Mut. Ins. Co., 44 Mass..raw_text: Young v. Patrons Mut. Ins. Co., 44 Mass. App. Ct. 372 (1998)
Young v. Patrons Mut. Ins. Co., 44 Mass..proposition: Serious or chronic violations of the State Sanitary Code are evidence of a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patrons Mut. Ins. Co., 44 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about assault, jury empanelment, peremptory challenges, batterer profile evidence, and prior bad acts. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, the State Sanitary Code, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss sanitary code violations as evidence of any breach. Therefore it cannot support the stated proposition.
Young v. Patrons Mut. Ins. Co., 44 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of the State Sanitary Code, housing conditions, landlord-tenant covenants, or quiet enjoyment. Its focus is on peremptory challenges, evidentiary issues in a criminal assault trial, and related procedural matters.

Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Spence v. O’Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Although this Complaint asserts only a cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, Plaintiff notes that Massachusetts law protects tenants from retaliatory conduct by landlords, including refusal to renew a lease after the tenant reports code violations.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. O’Brien deals with cause for eviction, notice requirements, grievance procedures, and the availability of defenses under G.L. c. 239, § 8A in the context of a public housing tenant whose apartment was used for drug activity. It does not address retaliatory eviction or non-renewal of a lease in response to a tenant’s reporting of code violations, nor does it discuss the Massachusetts statutory or common-law protections against retaliatory conduct by landlords. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition regarding retaliation for reporting code violations or refusal to renew a lease on that basis.
Spence v. O\u2019Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The Boston Housing Authority (BHA) brought a summary process action against Ellen O’Brien (tenant), claiming that she had allowed illegal drug transactions to occur on its premises... O’Brien argues that the trial judge was in error in refusing to allow her to raise the defense of uninhabitable conditions under G. L. c. 239, § 8A. She concedes that these defenses cannot be raised where an eviction is based upon wrongdoing, or fault, by the tenant... As we stated earlier, O’Brien was not without fault in that she knew of and tolerated Harris’ misconduct.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Although this Complaint asserts only a cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, Plaintiff notes that Massachusetts law protects tenants from retaliatory conduct by landlords, including refusal to renew a lease after the tenant reports code violations.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion in Young v. Patukonis deals with issues of heat and hot water obligations, security deposit violations, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability damages, and Chapter 93A applicability. It does not discuss retaliatory conduct, retaliatory eviction, or a landlord’s refusal to renew a lease after a tenant reports code violations. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition about Massachusetts’ protections against retaliatory refusal to renew a lease.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.

[No discussion of retaliatory conduct or refusal to renew a lease appears in the opinion.]
